original_data.question: A 47-year-old woman seeks evaluation at your office because she has had postcoital vaginal bleeding for the past 8 months with occasional intermenstrual watery, blood-tinged vaginal discharge. Her family history is negative for malignancies and inherited disorders. She is the result of a pregnancy complicated by numerous miscarriages in the 1960s, for which her mother received diethylstilbestrol. During a pelvic examination, you notice a polypoid mass on the anterior wall of the vagina. The bimanual examination is negative for adnexal masses. You suspect the presence of carcinoma and, therefore, send tissue samples to pathology, which confirmed the presence of malignant cells. Which of the following is the most likely malignant tumor in this patient?

model_response:
Clear cell adenocarcinoma is the most common type of vaginal cancer in young women. It is associated with in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol. Melanoma is a rare tumor that may arise in the vagina. It is more common in Caucasians. Botryoid sarcoma is a rare tumor that may affect the vagina. It is usually found in children. Verrucous carcinoma is a variant of squamous cell carcinoma that is more common in elderly women. It is well-differentiated and has a warty appearance.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Postcoital bleeding (PCB) consists of spotting or bleeding after sexual intercourse that is not related to a person's menstrual cycle. [PMID:25045355]
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Not occurring regularly or at short intervals.
A common gynecologic disorder characterized by an abnormal, nonbloody discharge from the genital tract.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.

An absence finding of the specified component / analyte, organism or clinical sign based on the established threshold of the performed test or procedure.

\[Note: Negative does not necessarily imply the complete absence of the specified item.\]

A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

A group of disorders involving predominantly the posterior portion of the ocular fundus, due to degeneration in the sensory layer of the RETINA; RETINAL PIGMENT EPITHELIUM; BRUCH MEMBRANE; CHOROID; or a combination of these tissues.
The result of an action.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
Difficult to analyze or understand.
An indefinite large quantity that is considered to be greater than several.
A loss of PREGNANCY from natural causes before the 20th week of pregnancy. (2017/18 ICD-10-CM)
Female parents, human or animal.

A synthetic nonsteroidal estrogen used in the treatment of menopausal and postmenopausal disorders. It was also used formerly as a growth promoter in animals. According to the Fourth Annual Report on Carcinogens (NTP 85-002, 1985), diethylstilbestrol has been listed as a known carcinogen. (Merck, 11th ed)
External and internal inspection of the FEMALE GENITALIA. (from Dictionary of Obstetrics and Gynecology)
A term that refers to a lesion that resembles a polyp.
The genital canal in the female, extending from the UTERUS to the VULVA. (Stedman, 25th ed)
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

An absence finding of the specified component / analyte, organism or clinical sign based on the established threshold of the performed test or procedure.

\[Note: Negative does not necessarily imply the complete absence of the specified item.\]
An abnormal growth in the ovary, fallopian tube, or surrounding connective tissue.
A malignant neoplasm made up of epithelial cells tending to infiltrate the surrounding tissues and give rise to metastases. It is a histological type of neoplasm and not a synonym for "cancer."

Collections of differentiated CELLS, such as EPITHELIUM; CONNECTIVE TISSUE; MUSCLES; and NERVE TISSUE. Tissues are cooperatively arranged to form organs with specialized functions such as RESPIRATION; DIGESTION; REPRODUCTION; MOVEMENT; and others.
A specialty concerned with the nature and cause of disease as expressed by changes in cellular or tissue structure and function caused by the disease process.
Cells of, or derived from, a malignant tumor.

A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
